statement.tex: %text Using integration, find the area bounded by the curves \[x^2 = 4y\text{ and the line }x = 4y-2. \] %

step.context: \textbf{What curves?} \\ %text Which of the figures below correctly shows the two curves? %
step.reason:
%text It might help you to re-write the equations, as shown below. % \begin{align} x^2 &= 4y \implies y = \dfrac{x^2}{4} \\ x &= 4y-2 \implies y = \dfrac{x}{4} + \dfrac{1}{2} \end{align} \\ %text Notice that in $y=\dfrac{x^2}{4}, y\geq 0$ for all $x$. Hence, one curve must be a parabola that opens upwards.
And as for $y=\dfrac{x}{4}+\dfrac{1}{2}$, it is a line with a positive slope and a y-intercept of $\frac{1}{2}$ (put $x=0$ to see where it cuts the y-axis). %

step.context: \textbf{Intersection of curves}\\ %text What are the coordinates of the points $P$ and $Q$ where the two curves intersect? %
step.reason: %text The two curves will intersect when % \begin{align} y = \dfrac{x^2}{4} &= \dfrac{x}{4} + \dfrac{1}{2} \\ \implies x^2 = x + 2 &\implies x^2 - x - 2 = 0 \\ \implies (x+1)\cdot (x-2) &= 0 \text{ or } x = -1, 2 \\ \therefore P = \underbrace{\left( -1,\frac{1}{4}\right)}_{y=\frac{x^2}{4}} &\text{ and } Q = \left(2,1 \right) \end{align}

step.context: \textbf{Right or wrong?}\\ %text The expression for the required area $A$ and its value is as follows. %
step.reason: %text In the range $(-1,2)$, the curve $x=4y-2$ \underline{\text{lies above}} the curve $x^2 = 4y$. Hence, the required area $A$ should be given by % \begin{align} A &= \int_{-1}^2 \dfrac{x+2}{4}\cdot dx - \int_{-1}^2\dfrac{x^2}{4}\cdot dx \\ &= \dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\int_{-1}^2 (x+2-x^2)\cdot dx \\ &= \dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\left[ \dfrac{x^2}{2}+2x-\dfrac{x^3}{3}\right]_{-1}^2 \\ &= \dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\left[ \left( \dfrac{4}{2}+4-\dfrac{8}{3}\right) - \left( \dfrac{1}{2}-2+\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\right]\\ &= \dfrac{9}{8} \end{align}
